keywords: Markrecapture, electrofishing, recovery period, fish behavior, catchability, assumptions.

abstract:
Mark-recapture is a method used to estimate fish populations by marking some individuals and then capturing and recapturing them at a later time (Mark-recapture electrofishing protocols). This technique helps measure sampling efficiency and generates population estimates, but it has limitations due to the recovery period between marking and recapture. Recovery periods longer than a single workday can make it difficult to maintain control over fish movement in small streams, violating the assumption of closed populations. Most authors suggest a minimum 24-hour recovery period.

The necessity of an appropriate recovery period arises from the need to ensure that marked and unmarked fish are equally catchable (critical assumption). This is crucial to obtain accurate population estimates. Studies have shown that behavioral or physiological differences between marked and unmarked fish can impact the recovery period needed for them to be equally catchable again.

In some cases, a shorter recovery period might suffice, as observed in a study where there was no significant difference in rainbow trout catchability between 24 hours and a 3-hour recovery period (Temple and Pearsons 2006). However, it's important to test this finding under different conditions before applying it widely.

Mark-recapture estimates can be biased if assumptions are not met in the field, but mark-recapture estimates tend to have less bias than multiple removal sampling. They are also more robust to poor crew experience and variable environmental conditions. However, the assumptions of this method should still be tested under real-world conditions to ensure accuracy.

description:
Mark-recapture electrofishing is a method used to assess sampling efficiency and generate population estimates of marked fish (Rodgers et al. 1992; Peterson et al. 2004). This technique involves marking fish with visible tags or fin clips, releasing them back into the water, and later recapturing and recording their marks to determine the proportion of marked versus unmarked fish captured.

However, a limitation of this method is the recovery period, which refers to the time elapsed between the marking and recapture sampling. Longer recovery periods, exceeding a single workday, pose challenges for controlling fish movement in small streams due to their dynamic nature (high flows or debris loads), violating the closed population assumption of the estimator (White et al. 1982). In such cases, electrofishing protocols extending beyond one working day become impractical for fisheries practitioners in many locations.

Authors commonly recommend a minimum 24-hour recovery period between marking and recapture sampling (Peterson et al. 2004; Mesa and Schreck 1989). Studies have shown that wild cutthroat trout resume normal behaviors after a 24-hour recovery period (Mesa and Schreck 1989), while Schreck et al. (1976) questioned the validity of mark-recapture estimates with shorter recovery periods. These recommendations are based on behavioral observations or physiological responses to electrofishing.

To ensure that marked and unmarked fish are equally catchable, it's essential to evaluate the appropriate recovery period between marking and recapture sampling (Peterson et al. 2004). This can be achieved by comparing the catchability of marked fish that have recovered for at least 24 hours versus those with shorter recoveries. The length of the shorter recovery period should allow both marking and recapture sampling to be completed in a single day.

A case study conducted in the Yakima River, Washington, reported no significant difference in rainbow trout catchability between fish that had recovered for 24 hours versus a 3-hour period (Temple and Pearsons 2006). This suggests that a 3-hour recovery period may be sufficient to allow marked rainbow trout to recover from handling. However, this finding needs to be validated in other areas under different conditions before being widely applied.

It's important to note that mark-recapture sampling, like multiple removal sampling, can produce biased estimates when assumptions are not met under field conditions (Peterson and Cederholm 1984; Rodgers et al. 1992). However, the severity of bias for mark-recapture estimates is generally lower than that reported for removal sampling. Mark-recapture estimates also exhibit robustness to potential bias introduced from poor crew experience or variable environmental conditions (channel type, habitat complexity, stream size). Nonetheless, it's crucial to test assumptions associated with mark-recapture estimates under field conditions.

target: Evaluating appropriate recovery periods for mark-recapture sampling.

This recommendation stems from behavioral observations (Mesa and Schreck, 1989) and physiological responses to electrofishing (Schreck et al., 1976). However, a case study in the Yakima River, Washington, showed that a 3-hour recovery period was sufficient for rainbow trout to recover from handling (Temple and Pearsons, 2006), but this finding needs to be tested under different conditions before it can be widely applied. This constraint ensures that the assumptions underlying the estimator are met, leading to accurate population estimates.
